subject: Re: [junit] chosing between jmock and easymock for mocks?
msgSnippet: ... CrazyBob writes in response to the question What do you think of JMock? ... Yuck. Not a fan at all. I hate the idea of using method names in strings.
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> I would pick EasyMock, especially since v2.0 which adds a lot of very cool
> Generic tricks to improve type safety.
>
> More details here:
>
> http://crazybob.org/2006/03/easymock-20-looks-promising.html

CrazyBob writes in response to the question "What do you think of JMock?"

----- CrazyBob -----
Yuck. Not a fan at all. I hate the idea of using method names in
strings. From the jMock web site (comparing jMock to EasyMock):

"We have found that the use of strings in jMock is not a huge
disadvantage, especially if you use an IDE that can apply refactorings
to names in string constants. Often when doing TDD, the method named in
an expectation will not yet be defined in any interface, and so code
completion cannot be used. We have found that the flexibility1 allowed
by the jMock API is better at reducing the work of refactoring than the
use of direct method calls."

Bullshit. I don't want to create a corresponding constant for every
method I mock. If I'm doing TDD (I don't), even if I code to a method
that doesn't exist yet, my IDE can generate the target method for me
based on my call. That won't work with JMock.

EasyMock code is more readable and the type checking and IDE support is
*much* better. I can't imagine what "flexibility" could possibly justify
the tradeoffs.

Generics have changed the playing field. EasyMock's API has stood up
well while jMock's has not.
----- CrazyBob -----

First, I don't know why he's creating a constant for every method he
mocks. If he lives in a world where all literals must be stored in a
constant, that's not jMock's fault. That's called "tyranny" and is bound
to bad for a number of other reasons.

Still, there's a flipside to the whole "can't generate a method stub"
argument. With EasyMock, if I use a faked or mocked method that doesn't
yet exist, my test can't even compile yet! When I practise TDD, I often
design interfaces, and forcing me to generate a method stub for a method
I might not even like yet is annoying. Keeping the methods as strings
allows me to write the test, compile it, and even run it before I decide
whether the interface or method signature is good enough to start
putting into stone.

As for EasyMock being more readable, EasyMock 1.x certainly wasn't. It
looks like EasyMock 2.0 gives jMock a run for its money, at least in the
easiest cases. The jury's out, since I haven't used it yet.

As for generics, well... it's no secret that I dislike generics, so I'll
let that comment pass. It might be right, but I don't care. :)
